questions.question_text: For which two components can an administrator add a machine template using image mappings? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
This is a very simple product knowledge test. 

We must understand what an "Image Mapping" is (it is a mapping between what VRA sees as a kind of VM image and what is provided by a cloud or on-prem provider). 

Only two of the answers, A and E, refer to VM providers. The other three cannot provide virtual machines, so how can an image mapping be created? 

The answer is A and E.

discussion.content:
I think the answer should be C. it's a newly created template in Cloud Assembly and the administrator is trying to import, not the user trying to use it. 
as in the ref doc says 'When you have a deployable template, you can now make it available in the Service Broker catalog for other uses to deploy. To make the cloud template discoverable so that you can add it to the catalog, you must release it.'
ref: https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/8.6/Using-and-Managing-Cloud-Assembly/GUID-3A721093-9648-45D2-BDEC-11E9F36833E4.html

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C. Just like most of these questions, 2 answers are very close. Yes, it is true that the template must be shared with the appropriate project, BUT, before you can even use it in ANY project, the template MUST be versioned so that a version can be 'Released' and be available in Service Broker at all. Also, in the question, there is a statement that a 'new' template is created, this further makes it clear since a new template always must have a released version. If there was a comment about an existing template version etc, then projects might make more sense. Read here: https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/8.11/Using-and-Managing-Cloud-Assembly/GUID-6D29DA24-A0C0-43AC-AFEF-F4EF4C3CB24E.html#releasing-a-version-to-service-broker-2

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer in my understanding is C, as the question is clear in saying that he wants to share this template only with the DevOps project team and it is a newly created model. He does not talk about sharing with more than one project, which would make alternative D the correct one. Therefore, for this question, I understand that the most correct option is C.

I don't think the question is worded very well. Depending on factors they did not mention, the reason could be A, C, or D. They are all valid reasons why a cloud template cannot be imported. But the question doesn't give enough information to know which one.
Which is it? C or D?

While D can also be correct, we don't know where the administrator is trying to share the template. It may or may not be correct.

Because C is more correct, I feel this is the way to go.

questions.question_text: Which command should an administrator run to ensure data integrity before a snapshot or backup of a vRealize Automation appliance? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content: before snapshot best option stop services - B

Answer is A

Using snapshots or creating a backup with an online VMware Aria Automation system causes issues because the database is not stored locally and data can be lost as a result.

To stop the services cleanly, run the `/opt/scripts/deploy.sh --onlyClean` script before taking a backup or a snapshot of the VMware Aria Automation appliance. You then run the `/opt/scripts/deploy.sh` script after the operation finishes to ensure services health and data integrity.

Taken from Aria Automation ICM 8.10 Lesson Book -> About the deploy.sh Script

Selected Answer: B
Correct is B.
Ref to below link - Pre-Snapshot Script include command /opt/scripts/svc-stop.sh and post snapshot script include command /opt/scripts/deploy.sh --onlyClean.

That means prior to backup/snapshot we do /opt/scripts/svc-stop.sh


see: https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Suite/2019/vrealize-suite-2019-backup-and-restore-avamar/GUID-49FA9AB6-2A69-4F41-80E1-495447F4D6FC.html

Selected Answer: B
i agree with D, to preserve data integrity we must shutdown the service, so the command must "start" with: /opt/scripts/deploy.sh --shutdown
